meanings.definition: Sensational journalism characterized by sensationalism and exaggeration.
meanings.sent1: The tabloidism in that article made the story seem more exciting than it really was.
meanings.sent2: The tabloidism of the news outlet often led to misleading headlines.
meanings.sent3: The tabloidism in the report about the alien invasion was so over-the-top that it made me chuckle.
meanings.sent4: Her storytelling had a touch of tabloidism, turning a simple event into a grand adventure.
meanings.sent5: The tabloidism of the magazine cover caught everyone's attention with its bold claims.

meanings.definition: The practice of focusing on trivial or sensational news stories.
meanings.sent1: Tabloidism in journalism sometimes overshadows important news with trivial stories.
meanings.sent2: The tabloidism of the media often results in exaggerated coverage of celebrity gossip.
meanings.sent3: The tabloidism of the newspaper's front page made me smile at the silliness of the headlines.
meanings.sent4: Her obsession with tabloidism led her to believe every sensational story she read.
meanings.sent5: The tabloidism of the news channel made it hard to find serious, informative content.

meanings.definition: The style or content typical of tabloid newspapers.
meanings.sent1: The tabloidism of the publication was evident in its bold fonts and attention-grabbing images.
meanings.sent2: Tabloidism often includes flashy headlines and dramatic photos to attract readers.
meanings.sent3: The tabloidism of the magazine's layout made it feel like a fun, guilty pleasure to read.
meanings.sent4: Her writing style had a hint of tabloidism, making even mundane events sound thrilling.
meanings.sent5: The tabloidism of the tabloids made them stand out on the newsstand with their eye-catching covers.
